Text.Name: Paragraph_about/text
Text.Text: The Orbital Material Science experiments are based on some real-life experiments carried out aboard the ISS. These experiments are aimed at the end-game and require a major orbital station and multiple launches to support the experiments. The basic concepts are: • Science Labs - these are orbital modules which provide room for researchers and Lab Equipemnt. • Lab Equipment - these must be installed in a Lab and support multiple experiments. • Experiments - these must be installed in specific Equipment Racks. Once an experiment is installed in a Lab, it can be run, which takes time. On completion, the experiment must be returned to Kerbin for detailed results analysis.

Text.Name: Page Heading/Page Subheading
Text.Text: General information about the NEOS experiments.

Text.Name: Paragraph_about/text
Text.Text: All experiments comprising NEOS are based on real-life experiments. Kemini is based on Gemini experiments. KEES is based on MIR experiments. OMS and KLS are based on ISS experiments.

Text.Name: Paragraph_about (1)/text
Text.Text: The experiments contained in NEOS require multiple steps to perform. In general, the stages are: 1. Preparing the experiment 2. Running the experiment 3. Finalizing the experiment 4. Recovering the experiment

Text.Name: Paragraph_about/text
Text.Text: The Kerbal Life Science experiments are based on some real-life experiments carried out aboard the ISS. The concept and execution is largely the same as for the OMS experiments, except that the science is carried out on Kerbals themselves! Each experiment requires one or more Kerbals as test subjects so be prepared to ship up plenty of victims, err, volunteers to your station!

Text.Name: Page Heading/Page Subheading
Text.Text: Kemini Experiments must be run in Orbit

Text.Name: Point1/text
Text.Text: Right-click on Command Pod and select "Run <Experiment>".

Text.Name: Point2/text
Text.Text: While the experiment is running, "Lab Time" slowly accrues.

Text.Name: Point3/text
Text.Text: When "Lab Time" is full, the experiment can be finished.

Text.Name: Point5/text
Text.Text: Which opens the "Review Experiment" window. Note: Kemini experiments cannot be reset.

Text.Name: Page Heading
Text.Text: Adding Kemini Experiments to your Craft

Text.Name: Page Heading/Page Subheading
Text.Text: You need to unlock Kemini experiment parts before you can add them to your Craft

Text.Name: Point2/Text2
Text.Text: Unlock the Kemini Part(s) you want.

Text.Name: Point1/Text1
Text.Text: Research the node(s) which hold the Kemini parts.

Text.Name: Point3/Text3
Text.Text: Right-click on a Command Pod and select "Add Experiment" from the menu. Note: Not all Command Pods support Kemini.

Text.Name: Point4/Text4
Text.Text:
A menu of available Kemin experiments will open.
Select the experiment you want to add to the Command Pod.

Text.Name: Paragraph_about/text
Text.Text: The Kemini Research Program is based on some real-life experiments carried out during the Gemini missions. It is aimed at the early game and only requires the "Mk1 Command Pod". After unlocking experiemnts in the Research and Development Centre, you can add them to your capsule and carry out experiments in orbit. Look out for Kemini missions too!

Text.Name: Page Heading/Page Subheading
Text.Text: Once an Experiment has been mounted, there are a few steps required to run one.

Text.Name: Fig1_attach_pec/Caption
Text.Text: Fig 3.1 - Mounting an Experiment on a PEC.

Text.Name: Point1/Text
Text.Text:
Drag an Experiment from a KIS Inventory onto the PEC.
Any Kerbal can do this, and you don't even need to EVA!

Text.Name: Point2/Text
Text.Text: Experiment mounted and ready to be run.

Text.Name: Page Heading/Page Subheading
Text.Text: Individual KEES Experiments have to be mounted on a PEC attached to a vessel.

Text.Name: Fig1_attach_pec/Caption
Text.Text: Fig 3.1 - Mounting an Experiment on a PEC.

Text.Name: Point1/Text
Text.Text:
Drag an Experiment from a KIS Inventory onto the PEC.
Any Kerbal can do this, and you don't even need to EVA!

Text.Name: Point2/Text
Text.Text: Experiment mounted and ready to be run.

Text.Name: Page Heading/Page Subheading
Text.Text: Once in orbit, you need to perform some assembly before running the experiments.

Text.Name: Point1/Text
Text.Text: Unlock the research nodes containing the KEES parts.

Text.Name: Point2/Text
Text.Text: Build your vessel in the VAB. Add the KEES parts to any KIS containers on your vessel, such as the KEES Payload Carrier.

Text.Name: Point3/Text
Text.Text: Don't forget to take a spanner!

Text.Name: Page Heading/Page Subheading
Text.Text: Add unlocked KEES parts to your vessel's KIS containers

Text.Name: Point1/Text
Text.Text: Unlock the research nodes containing the KEES parts.

Text.Name: Point2/Text
Text.Text: Build your vessel in the VAB. Add the KEES parts to any KIS containers on your vessel, such as the KEES Payload Carrier.

Text.Name: Point3/Text
Text.Text: Don't forget to take a spanner!

Text.Name: Paragraph_about/text
Text.Text: The Kemini Environmental Effects Studies experiments are based on some real-life experiments carried out during the MIR missions. These experiments are aimed at the mid-game and require some basic orbital construction using KIS. The experiments are deployed on a Passive Experiment Carrier (PEC) which must be attached to the outside of your spacecraft, which requires an Engineer. Once the PEC is attached to your craft, any Kerbal can deploy and retrieve the experiments. The basic idea is to launch a minimal spacestation and attach a PEC to it, then run resupply missions to swap experiments. This mod benefits greatly from 2-Kerbal command pods such as the K2 or Corvus.
